awd_titl_txt: Physical and Numerical Experiments of Slip Partitioning under Oblique Strike-slip
awd_abstract_narration:
Much attention is focused on the main strands of major strike-slip faults, such as the San Andreas Fault in California, for their potential to generate large devastating earthquakes. However, non-strike slip motion associated with these large faults is often accommodated on secondary faults, which may also be the source of large earthquakes as demonstrated in the 2010 Haiti earthquake. The tectonic conditions that cause slip along these secondary faults are not fully understood. This project uses a combination of physical and computer modeling experiments to better understand why slip takes place on these secondary faults rather than the main fault. The proposed research advances desired societal outcomes through: (1) full participation of women and persons with disabilities in STEM through support of a hearing-impaired female PI and a female graduate student; (2) continued mentoring of deaf and hearing-impaired students; (3) improved STEM education through posting of animations from analog experiments on YouTube and web cam broadcast of experiments Google+ Hangouts transmissions; (4) development of a globally competitive STEM workforce through graduate student training; and (5) a better understanding of earthquake hazards along fault systems such as the San Andreas Fault.

This project uses physical and numerical experiments to investigate slip partitioning along strike-slip systems within two types of settings, oblique plate motion and restraining bends. Both of these settings are observed to have slip partitioned faults with strike-slip along vertical fault strands and oblique slip along dipping fault strands, but the loading differs between the models. The physical experiments will test the conditions under which strike-slip faults develop outward verging secondary faults. The experiments explore the controls on and thresholds for slip partitioning and will quantify the nature of slip partitioning within these systems. The analog models utilize wet kaolin to simulate a range of oblique strike-slip boundary conditions that explore the conditions for secondary contractional fault development. The physical experiments data include measurements of the evolving horizontal displacement field using digital image correlation, changes in uplift patterns using stereo imaging, measurements of dilational stress using pressure transducers and estimates of relative water flux along faults using an infrared camera. The data from the analog experiments will be used to track the evolution of kinematic efficiency to test if slip partitioned systems accommodate oblique convergence more efficiently than non-partitioned systems. Numerical simulations of the experiments will assess the work budget of the slip partitioned systems and test if the fault systems evolve to minimize work. 3D numerical simulations of the various experimental setups will provide complete stress and strain fields that facilitate calculation of the complete work budget within the system. This will provide insights, for example, on the tradeoffs between work against gravity and internal deformation as the fault system evolves. The combined physical and numerical investigations in this proposed study will provide a critical bridge between theories of slip partitioning under oblique strike-slip and geologic and experimental observations.

por.por_cntn:
The largest earthquakes in the world occur along subduction zones where two tectonics plates are converging together. Along some of these margins the plates have both strike-slip (side-by-side) as well as convergent motion, which we describe as oblique convergence. Interestingly, many oblique convergent plate margins have two active fault systems, one that accommodates convergence and another that accommodates strike-slip rather that one fault system that accommodates oblique slip. This partitioning of slip complicates the prediction of seismic hazards. In this study, we investigated how these slip partitioned fault systems with two active faults each with different slip develop and how they are maintained.

To document fault system evolution, table-top experiments use wet clay that is scaled to simulate the same physics of faulting within the crust. With experiments we can directly document the detailed fault evolution in the lab that takes millions of years in the crust. We set up two types of oblique convergence experiments (Fig 1). One sets the clay over blocks that move so that the whole boundary experiences oblique convergence. The other suite of experiments simulates a contractional bend in another otherwise straight strike-slip fault. The material around this ‘restraining bend’ experiences oblique convergence. In addition to using Digital Image Correlation to record the horizontal displacements throughout the experiment, we implement an innovative stereovision technique to document the cumulative uplift throughout fault evolution (Toenenboehn et al., 2018). This allows us to track the 3D path of material around faults. Such data from restraining bend experiments is valuable to geoscientists who are trying to unravel the probable transport path of rocks from their chemistry that records uplift.

Within the suite of experiments that apply oblique convergence to the entire experiment, all experiments produce two active faults, but the sequence and pattern of faulting depends on both the convergence angle and whether we pre-cut vertical fault in the clay before the experiment (Cooke et al., 2020). The presence of a precut vertical weakness in the clay impacts the morphology of faults but is not required for slip partitioning. In low convergent angle experiments, the strike-slip fault forms before the ‘reverse’ fault, which is the kind of fault that accommodates convergence.  In contrast, within experiments with greater convergence, the reverse fault forms before the strike-slip fault.

The experiments show that development of two active fault surfaces rather than just one obliquely slipping fault arises from the off-fault strain pattern that develop after the first fault shows up (Fig. 2). For experiments that develop vertical strike-slip faults first, contraction accumulates around the fault that promotes the development of a new reverse fault. Within experiments that develop reverse faults first, these faults can’t accommodate much strike-slip due to their corrugated shape. The reverse faults also produce nearby extension, which, together with off-fault shear, promotes the development of strike-slip faults. The observation of persistent slip partitioning under a wide range of experimental conditions demonstrates why such systems are frequently observed in oblique convergence crustal margins that produce devasting earthquakes around the world.

Within experiments of restraining bends along strike-slip faults, we vary the angle of restraining bend and document the development of new faults. In effort to understand better fault development within the experiments we also set up 3D numerical simulations of the restraining bends. The distribution of slip along the faults in the numerical model and the accumulation of strain around the faults resembles the observations from the clay experiments. The successful comparison shows how strain not accommodated along faults contributes to the development of new faults.  This understanding can guide seismic hazard estimates of restraining bends in the Earth’s crust where active slip is distributed among many parallel faults.

Videos of all of our fault system evolution experiments are posted on the UMass Claybox YouTube channel.  Educators anywhere can use these animations in their classrooms. To facilitate understanding of the experiments, we have also posted some explanatory videos with voice over and captions that explain both the way that we do experiments and what the results mean.

Broader Impacts: Most academics with deafness work at predominantly hearing institutions where their isolation prevents them from learning from each other how to thrive in academia. The Mind Hears blog (www.themindhears.org) was started by the PI, Cooke, and colleague Caicedo as a way to share experiences, learn from each other, and promote deaf and hard of hearing academics. The blog has had 27 posts including three profiles of academics from the US, Canada and the UK. The posts have had >8500 views from around the world. Many have reported that they never knew of any other deaf or hard of hearing academics until they found this network. The resources that The Mind Hears is building will serve to promote the success of many academics and diversify academia.

 

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2020
Modified by: Michele L Cooke

  • Fig 2: Strain maps after the first fault forms. A) Convergence around the strike-slip fault promotes reverse fault growth. B) Off-fault shear strain next to curvy reverse faults promotes strike slip fault growth. C) Unclamping next to first reverse fault promotes slip on nearby faults.
    Michele Cooke

  • Figure 1: A) and B) Set up of experiments of oblique convergence along the entire margin. C) Experimental set up for restraining bend experiments that have oblique convergence within the restraining bend. (A&B taken from Cooke et al. 2020. C taken from Toeneboehn et al., 2018)
